description: From Middle English abbesse, from Old French abeesse (French abbesse), from Late Latin or Ecclesiastical Latin abbatissa, feminine of Latin abbas, abbatis (“abbot”).

entries.meaning: A female superior or governess of a nunnery, or convent of nuns, having the same authority over the nuns which the abbots have over the monks. [First attested around 1150 to 1350]
examples: The abbess was always after the nuns to keep the convent immaculately clean.

entries.meaning: (archaic, British slang) A woman who runs a brothel; a woman employed by a prostitute to find clients.
